description.narrative: Accelerator Labs Project objective is to build a network of 60 Country Accelerator Labs as the largest, fastest global learning network on development challenges.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Output 1 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. Output 2 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies Output 3 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative: Baseline value for all output indicators = 0 Year = 2018

Output 1 2 new sources of data per year 3 different type of data sources per year 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 2 innovation methods per Action Plan Output 2 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. Output 3 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1 2 new sources of data per year - Assessment of Business Development Centres (Biashara Centres) to explore the effectiveness of such models in addressing youth unemployment - Mapping priority development areas with diverse partners to inform the focus area of the Acc Lab
3 different type of data sources per year - Citizen-generated data with university students to understand key drivers of youth unemployment - Ecosystem mapping of the Kenyan innovation system to understand the stakeholders and value proposition of the Acc Lab
20 new potential solutions per lab per year - 5 solutions mapped from solutions safari in Wajir in December 2019 - 15 solutions mapped through the Generation Unlimited Youth Challenge
2 innovation methods per Action Plan - Collective intelligence: co-creating the development agenda for the Acc Lab with diverse stakeholders in the Kenyan innovation ecosystem. - Sensemaking: CO portfolio sensemaking with Programme colleagues to understand linkages and opportunities for collaboration with the Acc Lab - Solutions mapping: solutions mapping safaris to map community-led grassroots solutions
Output 2 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. - 2 blogs published on the Acc Lab stakeholder consultative forum and launch in Kenya
At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. - Partners included in learning cycle include: Strategic Initiatives Unit of the Office of the President and Aga Khan University (AKU) Graduate School of Media and Communications; Council of Governors.
At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. - Lab methods shared with government stakeholders at the Acc Lab Stakeholder Consultative Forum – Ministry of ICT, Youth and Innovation & Office of the President
At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. - Insights from the Business Development Centre assessments used as a base for programme design of youth empowerment programme under the Inclusive Growth portfolio.
Output 3 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year - Lab members took part in the weekly global Acc Lab calls and webinars. - Lab members shared weekly reflections, portfolio experiment designs, action plans and more on the global Acc Lab MS Teams channels and WhatsApp platforms. - Lab members participated in the global Acc Lab bootcamp in September 2019.
5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. - Acc Lab’s external engagements like the stakeholder consultative forum and launch events were featured on the CO platforms. Lab team members regularly shared progress through personal social media accounts, more than once per month
Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. - Acc Lab team members took part in external forums and engagements like Tallberg/ Eliasson Workshop at Strathmore University with members of the Kenyan Senate.

Output 1 5 new sources of data per year 6 different type of data sources per year 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 5 innovation methods per Action Plan Output 2 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. Output 3 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1 5 new sources of data per year - Impact of COVID-19 on MSMEs conducted with MSME Authority of Kenya - Digital inclusion webinars- 4 webinars with youth aged between 18-24 - Impact of COVID-19 on Creative Sector- Survey conducted by HEVA Fund, one of our partners. - Innovation Ecosystem mapping and analysis through the Innovation Challenges (Great COVID-19 Innovation Challenge, Disability Innovation Challenge, Creatives Innovation Challenge) - Mapping supply chain for COVID-19 PPE with Ministry of Industrialisation and UNIDO
6 different type of data sources per year - Social media analysis on COVID-19 misinformation - Geospatial data – Enabled us to get an overview of the location-based factors of informal markets in Nairobi. When mapped, we could tell that most of these markets are clustered near informal settlements. There is currently no data on all the markets and their characteristics. It was necessary to have this information to help us decide where we needed to focus our experiments informed by maximum reach. - Social media data – We looked at instances where NHIF was trending and conducted a sentiment analysis of user conversations to complement the ethnographic study. This was necessary to help NHIF understand the social sentiment of their service while monitoring online conversations. - Large scale public dialogue/FGDs – Worked with popular radio stations to broadcast interactive radio discussions on citizens’ views on NHIF. Data was then gathered through SMS questionnaires and analysed to gain rich insights into the citizens’ perceptions on provision and quality of health services. This information when triangulated with what came up during the ethnographic study, stakeholder co-creation workshop and training of champions cemented the need for practical information on the NHIF service. - Use of Innovation challenges to map grassroots solutions and uncover trends and insights on the impact of COVID-19 to the broader innovation ecosystem and how that affects minority groups like youth and PWDs - Web scrapping on the trends of work during COVID-19
35 new potential solutions per lab per year - 40 solutions mapped from the Great COVID-19 Innovation Challenge - 5 solutions mapped from the Disability Innovation Challenge - 9 solutions mapped from the Creatives innovation challenge - 5 solutions mapped through solutions safari with informal market vendors
5 innovation methods per Action Plan - Ethnography – immersions in informal markets on social protection - Positive deviance – social protection portfolio - Design thinking – prototyping with winners of Great COVID-19 innovation challenge - Gamification – addressing COVID-19 misinformation at community level - Collective intelligence – unpacking the digital inclusion challenge with diverse stakeholders - Prototyping – building and testing low-cost solutions to minimise spread of COVID-19 with local innovators from the global Hackster Detect & Protect Challenge - Co-creation – We undertook a participatory virtual stakeholder co-creation workshop with a diverse array of stakeholders that enabled people to have conversations, share perspectives and challenge each other’s thinking to arrive at an integrated understanding of the low health insurance coverage challenge and how it could be addressed. - Participatory design – By mapping stakeholders and training them as NHIF agents, we sought to build a natural network of collaborators as we thought about collective impact. We were able to see problems and opportunities from multiple perspectives. In addition, consultations with key stakeholders enabled us to identify key evidence gaps to be filled by citizen voice. - Positive deviants – The insights from the ethnographic study revealed that a good number of those who had voluntarily insured themselves had previously benefitted from the service. These were mostly those who had benefitted from the surgical package which tends to be costly. The test phase seeks to leverage the positive testimonials of these clients. - Systems thinking – From the field visits and virtual stakeholder co-creation forum, we mapped out all the factors that we needed to consider into various fields: cultural, psychological, sociological, technological, economic, demographic, biological, political and legislative. - Solutions mapping – We learnt that factors that affect design of a context specific health insurance model can come from not just technology developments, market results, media and the internet but all kinds of different sources such as internet cafes. - Ethnography – Even though the available data were useful and provided direction, they had been formulated quite narrowly. For example, “84 per cent of the Kenyan workforce is active in the informal economy” is a useful but narrow way to define the context of the informal economy in the country. In order to explore the context of the informal economy and low health insurance coverage among informal economy workers, we had to visit NHIF’s intended users, observe the way they did things, talk with them and reflect. - Data Visualization – The portfolio wheel helped us analyse the various factors and communicate our thoughts with various stakeholders during the insight validation sessions
Output 2 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. - 10 blogs published on UNDP Kenya, global UNDP Accelerator Lab and Singapore Global Centre platforms.
At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. - Public sector partners involved: MSEA; NHIF; Ministry of ICT, Youth and Innovation (MoICT); Ministry of Health; Youth Enterprise Development Fund (YEDF)
At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. - Embedding Acc Lab methodologies such as collective intelligence and participatory design in YEDF and NHIF, - Leveraging the UNDP Acc Lab model to co-create a combined SDG Acc Lab with the MoICT and other UN agencies like UNICEF and FAO
At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. - Providing insights and contributions to the design and implementation of 2 COVID-19 response projects under the ERU portfolio. - Partnering with Transcending Peace programme under Governance portfolio to develop an innovative intervention approach to address peace and security with a focus on PWDs. - Through exploration and sensemaking, facilitated linkages with a new partner for the Anti-corruption method to test innovative approach of sentiment analysis from citizen-generated radio data using machine learning tools.
Output 3 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year - Lab members took part in the weekly global Acc Lab calls and webinars. - Lab members shared weekly reflections, portfolio experiment designs, action plans and more on the global Acc Lab MS Teams channels and WhatsApp platforms. - Lab members participated in the global Acc Lab bootcamp in October 2020. - Acc Lab Kenya facilitated a knowledge exchange and learning session with other Labs in the East Africa region including South Sudan, Ethiopia in April 2020.
25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. - Lab members shared weekly reflections, portfolio experiment designs, action plans and more on the global Acc Lab MS Teams channels. Additionally, Acc Lab has been part of several high-level discussions such as UNDP-UKRI workshop and UNDP-JICA AfriConverse. - Worked with UNDP Crisis Bureau on a Digital Assessment of the impact of COVID-19 on MSMEs in Kenya. Worked with UNDP Singapore Centre on the Cultivate Challenge looking at innovations for food security and Hackster COVID-19 Challenge to test low-cost DIY solutions to minimise the spread of the virus.
The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. - Acc Lab’s blogs and work featured on the CO platforms and generated feedback and responses from diverse audience. Lab team members regularly shared progress through personal social media accounts, more than once per month. - - Acc Lab’s blogs featured several times on global UNDP channels like the weekly UNDP COVID-19 Bulletin, monthly Acc Labs newsletters and annual Acc Lab report.
Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. - Acc Lab’s work featured in newspapers and publications including the UNDP Futures Report and Star newspaper. Acc Lab team members featured in panels like Webinar on Decent Work hosted by Ministry of ICT through Konza Technopolis. - Acc Labs work on misinformation drew interest from local partners like Aga Khan Graduate School of Media Studies; Code for Africa and Pesa Check. - Acc Labs work on social protection for informal sector workers generated insights feeding into the broader informal sector strategy led by ILO. - Acc Labs COVID-19 systems map generated interest from other development partners like DFID and USAID who reached out for further exploratory discussions.

Output 1 10 new sources of data per year 9 different type of data sources per year 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 10 innovation methods per Action Plan Output 2 At least 8 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
